issue.title: Automatically configure subcommands via `list_submodules`.

labels.name: cla-signed
labels.description: [bot] added once the contributor has signed the CLA

issue.body:
### Description
Automatically search subcommands by calling `list_submodules` util function, so that we can execute their `configure_parser` function in `conda.cli.conda_argparse.generate_parser` easily, see https://github.com/conda/conda/pull/13242/commits/425dfbe76ea27ee9c8cefc5e67f1dd8ea4347a5b.

===
IMO with `list_submodules` function, we can make this repo to be easier to add new commands. In the end, for creating a new command, the only thing we need to do will be created a new file that named as `main_<xxx>.py` (based on `TEMPLATE.md`) in `command` folder, rather than like now, we need to copy/paste those command names and paths everywhere in the source code.
This PR is mainly for demonstration, it is only meant to improve the maintainability and should not change or break any existing behavior.
Before continuing to modify the remain code, I would like to hear some feedback. :)

### Checklist - did you ...

- [ ] Add a file to the `news` directory ([using the template](../blob/main/news/TEMPLATE)) for the next release's release notes?
- [x] Add / update necessary tests?
- [x] Add / update outdated documentation?

comment.body:
@scruel,

The subcommand plugin hooks can also be used for internal commands. For example, we have recently add a new `conda doctor` command and have chosen to go this route:

- https://github.com/conda/conda/tree/main/conda/plugins/subcommands

In the future, a more meaningful refactor would actually be to move all commands to this directory, so that they are all registered as "internal" plugins. You can see another example of this by looking at the "quetz" project (https://github.com/mamba-org/quetz)

The refactoring that we are currently doing here https://github.com/conda/conda/pull/13173 is relate to our work here:

- https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/11633

Although it's not on the roadmap yet, after completing that epic, we could very well move to refactor all conda subcommands as internally registered subcommand plugins.

We really appreciate your interest in this! Keep the questions coming if you have them 😄.

issue.title: Convert canary builds to be noarch

labels.name: cla-signed
labels.description: [bot] added once the contributor has signed the CLA

issue.body:
There is no technical reason why a package build on macos-{64, arm64} or linux-{64, ppc64le, s390x} should be any different. So building two noarch variants of conda, one for unix and one for windows. The run constrain ensures that only the right variant can be installed.

While its is the goal of prod/defaults to build recipes for all platform / python combination to e.g. reveal if dependencies are missing in some of the combinations, the the goal of conda canary releases may differ in this regards to make canary builds as easy testable as possible on all platforms / python combinations.

Inspired by https://github.com/conda-forge/constructor-feedstock/blob/main/recipe/meta.yaml

issue.title: Download largest packages first

labels.name: type::feature
labels.description: request for a new feature or capability

labels.name: tag::performance
labels.description: related to degraded performance

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched for other speed issues and didn't find a duplicate

### What happened?

Download packages by largest size first as suggested by https://cfp.packaging-con.org/2023/talk/VZUZ9Y/

This also helps with "slow download falls off the screen" since the progress bar for e.g. tensorflow will be up top.

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched open requests and couldn't find a duplicate

### What is the idea?

Governance is now mature enough to exist in conda instead of conda-incubator.

We have a Code of Conduct Committee, our Code of Conduct has been written, we're also now fiscally sponsored by NumFOCUS. 

### What should happen?

- [ ] [Governance](https://github.com/conda-incubator/governance) should be migrated to conda from conda-incubator.

issue.title: Implement resume partial/incomplete package downloads

labels.name: type::feature
labels.description: request for a new feature or capability

labels.name: source::community
labels.description: catch-all for issues filed by community members

labels.name: pending::discussion
labels.description: contains some ongoing discussion that needs to be resolved prior to proceeding

labels.name: severity::3
labels.description: major; broken functionality with a workaround

labels.name: backlog
labels.description: issue has been triaged but has not been earmarked for any upcoming release

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched open requests and couldn't find a duplicate

### What is the idea?

This feature request is readdressing past requests for providing a resume feature in conda:
https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/7
https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/800

As AI models and their supporting tools are now in the 1GB+ size, for those of us in countries where electricity and internet are consistently interrupted or slow, it's proving almost impossible to complete large updates. For example, pytorch-2.0.1-py3.10_cuda11.8_cudnn8_0.tar.bz2 has never completed in the last 24 hours and each restart starts from the beginning. Even for people in locations with fast internet, building in redundancy and resume logic will help reduce network congestion.

Possible implementation strategies may include:

- allow option for alternate download tool (wget, ...)
- check for partial downloads and complete those before starting a fresh download
- allow check/option for removing orphaned downloads

I am happy to be a tester for any effort applied to this feature request.



### Why is this needed?

As AI models and their supporting tools are now in the 1GB+ size, for those of us in countries where electricity and internet are consistently interrupted or slow, it's proving almost impossible to complete large updates.

### What should happen?

**Current:** 
User: conda install pytorch==2.0.0 torchvision==0.15.0 torchaudio==2.0.0 pytorch-cuda=11.7 -c pytorch -c nvidia

System: hangs or aborts about 2-3 hours

User: conda install pytorch==2.0.0 torchvision==0.15.0 torchaudio==2.0.0 pytorch-cuda=11.7 -c pytorch -c nvidia

System: Starts downloading all packages from the beginning!

**Ideal:**
User: conda install pytorch==2.0.0 torchvision==0.15.0 torchaudio==2.0.0 pytorch-cuda=11.7 -c pytorch -c nvidia

System: hangs or aborts about 2-3 hours

User: conda install pytorch==2.0.0 torchvision==0.15.0 torchaudio==2.0.0 pytorch-cuda=11.7 -c pytorch -c nvidia

System: Continues downloading all packages from where it was interrupted

### Additional Context

_No response_

commits.message:
Resume downloads / refactor download() function (#13231)

* Support resuming downloads.
* replace hardcoded errno with ConnectionResetError
* move lock to prevent circular imports
* improved code coverage

---------

Co-authored-by: el-g-1 <elleng.willowtree@gmail.com>

pull_request.title: Resume downloads / refactor download() function
pull_request.body:
<!-- Hello! Thanks for submitting a PR! To help make things go a bit more
     smoothly, we would appreciate it if you follow this template. -->

### Description

Fix #12752 

Begin by refactoring `download()` function, moving error handling outside of main function.

I've made this so that partial downloads only happen when size, hash is given which I think is done for packages. "Only resume partial download if etag matches" would be a different classic move.

I tested this by turning off wifi during a download. CTRL-C handling during parallel downloads is poor and does not stop most downloads. #13234 

The progress bars didn't initially make it to 100%, they did not take the already-downloaded content into account, should be working with latest revision.

The hashes didn't match when I'd typed in the 206 response code incorrectly, this is fixed and tested now.

I check the hash of `.partial` before putting it on its destination, but delete `.partial` for 4xx HTTP errors that are unlikely to succeed on retry. Unlike the current system that might leave files with the wrong hash but correct filename.

Does the current code check the hash of already-downloaded packages before unpacking?

issue.title: Use conda-package-streaming in package_cache_data?

labels.name: type::feature
labels.description: request for a new feature or capability

labels.name: tag::performance
labels.description: related to degraded performance

issue.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched for other speed issues and didn't find a duplicate

### What happened?

[class PackageCacheData](https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/main/conda/core/package_cache_data.py#L424) appears to extract a package just to read its `index.json` in specific circumstances. I'm not sure whether this always happens right before installation, where we would want the package to be unpacked anyway, or at other times.

Instead, use `conda-package-streaming` to read `index.json`. This is shown in its test suite https://github.com/conda/conda-package-streaming/blob/main/tests/test_streaming.py#L18-L33

### Debug
